title: Achilles Tendonopathy Case Study: A 45-Year-Old Male Runner
clinical_history: A 45-year-old male, avid runner, presented with a 6-week history of right ankle pain. He reported a gradual onset of pain and stiffness in the Achilles tendon region, which worsened over time. The patient noted that the pain is more pronounced in the mornings and after running. He has been training for a marathon and increased his running distance by 20% over the past 3 months.
aggrevating_factors: running, especially uphill or with quick changes of direction; jumping; landing from jumps; and morning stiffness
picture: A 24-hour picture of the patient's symptoms shows that the pain is worse in the morning (8/10) and improves slightly throughout the day, but worsens again after running or jumping activities.
easing_factors: rest; ice; stretching; and heel lifts
past_history: history of ankle sprains (2 times) 5 and 7 years ago; overuse injuries in the past, including shin splints and plantar fasciitis
medical_history: generally healthy; takes NSAIDs as needed for pain
medications: ibuprofen 400mg 3 times a day as needed
personal_history: married with two children; works as an accountant; enjoys running and hiking in his free time
imaging: Ultrasound imaging revealed tendinosis and thickening of the Achilles tendon, with no signs of rupture
